Speaker: senator 1
Dialogue: ... but if we hesitate we'll lose this important source of dilithium. A trade agreement is in the best interests of the Empire.

Speaker: senator 2
Dialogue: Praetor, I recommend we dispatch a diplomatic mission to Celes II to open negotiations.

Speaker: praetor
Dialogue: Senator Tal'Aura, you disagree with the motion.

Speaker: praetor
Dialogue: Then I will call for a vote on the motion to open trade negotiations with Celes II...

Speaker: praetor
Dialogue: Would someone please tell me what that was?  Alert security --

Speaker: praetor
Dialogue: -- and have them run a --

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Duty...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: A starship captain's life is filled with solemn duty.  I have commanded men in battle.  I have negotiated peace treaties between implacable enemies.  I have represented the Federation in first contact with twenty-seven alien species.  But none of this compares to my solemn duty as... Best man.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Now, I know that on an occasion such as this: it is expected that I be gracious and fulsome with praise on the wonders of this blessed union... But have you two considered what you're doing to? This is all a damned inconvenience...  ... Then there's the matter of my new counselor.  Undoubtedly some soft-spoken, willowy thing who'll be probing into my darkest psyche as she nods her head and coos sympathetically.  Isn't that right, Deanna?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I notice Dr. Crusher laughing along with the rest of you.  As most of you know, the doctor will also soon be leaving the Enterprise, to assume command of Starfleet Medical.  Again, I'm forced to ask, Beverly, have you considered what you're doing to little ole' me?! I'll probably get some old battle- axe of a doctor who'll tell me to eat my vegetables and put me on report if I don't show up for my physical on time!

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: It'll serve you right.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Really, it's not too late to reconsider.  No?  Very well then...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Will Riker, you have been my trusted right arm for fourteen years; you have helped keep my course true and steady.  Deanna Troi, you have been my conscience and best guide, the touchstone to the better parts of myself.  You are my family.  And in proper maritime tradition I wish you full sails and a clear horizon... My friends, make it so.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Sort of like losing a son and gaining an empath, isn't it?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Please, Beverly, this is hard enough.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: If you start tearing up I promise to beam you out.  Level one medical emergency.  There's no crying in Starfleet.

Speaker: leah
Dialogue: I've never seen your Captain so nostalgic.  Maybe he's getting soft in his old age.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Not likely.  After we installed the new Series Four replicators, he tried to order his usual tea and there was a glitch.  Had us remove the whole bunch of them and put the old ones back in.

Speaker: leah
Dialogue: There!  Nostalgic about old replicators.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: He just likes things the way he likes them...  Of course, so do I.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Romulan ale should be illegal.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: It is, old chum.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Then it should be more illegal.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: Really, Captain, it was a lovely toast.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: The least I could do for you, Deanna.  Besides, you know me... I'm a talking head.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: And you needn't worry.  I'll brief your new counselor on everything she needs to know.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: The hell you will.  You know too much about me as it is... Now you promised there are no speeches during the ceremony on Betazed.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: No, no speeches.  No clothes either.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Ladies and Gentlemen and invited Tran gendered species... In my study of Terran and Betazoid conjugal rites I have discovered it is traditional to present the "happy couple" with a gift.  Given Commander Riker's affection for archaic musical forms I have elected to present the following as my gift in honor of their conjugation.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: If you please, Mister Band Leader, a-one and a-two and...

Speaker: data
Dialogue: "Blue skies, smiling at me, Nothing but blue skies do I see.  Blue birds, singing a song, Nothing but blue birds all day long.  Never saw the sun shining so bright, Never saw things going so right..."

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Ugghhh... Irving Berlin.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: All right, go ahead.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: May I have this dance?

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: With pleasure, Captain.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Commander Worf... Do Klingons swing?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: I am not a swinger.  I am unwell.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Don't worry, I'm a doctor.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: I'm so glad you made it back to the Enterprise before I left.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: I was not suited for the life of a... diplomat.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Who'd have guessed?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I've been saving this.  Chateau Picard 2267.  Batten down the hatches...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: They say a vintner's history is in every glass.  The soil he came from.  His past as well as his hopes for the future.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: So... To happy endings.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: To happy endings.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Sir.  I noticed an interesting confluence of emotion at the wedding.  I am familiar with the human concept of tears through laughter and its inverse, laughter through tears, but I could not help wondering about the human capacity for expressing both pleasure and sadness simultaneously.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I understand why it would seem confusing.  Certain human rituals -- like weddings, birthdays or funerals evoke strong and very complex emotions.  These rites carry great weight with us because they denote the passage of time.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: And you were particularly aware of this feeling because Commander Riker will be leaving to assume command of the Titan?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Will and Deanna joining the Titan. Dr. Crusher going to Starfleet Medical...

Speaker: data
Dialogue: And this makes you "sad"?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Well.  I suppose it does a bit. I'm very happy for them, of course, but I'm going to miss them.  The ship will seem... incomplete without them.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: That is because you have a familiarity with them.  You can predict specific reactions and behavior and are comfortable in that knowledge.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes.  And, frankly, I envy them as well.  They've made important choices; they're going to have great challenges ahead of them. New worlds to conquer...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Seeing Will and Deanna today made me think about some of the choices I've made in my own life.  Devoting myself to Starfleet... Not marrying or having children... All the choices that led me here.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: The choices I made have led me here as well.  This is the only home I have ever known.  I cannot foresee a reason for leaving.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You never know what's over the horizon, Data.  Before too long you'll be offered a command of your own.  Data looks at him; he has never really considered this.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: If I were... I believe my memory engrams would sense the absence of your specific reactions and behavior.  I would "miss you."

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Now, you make a toast.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: To new worlds...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: New worlds.  Yes Data, brave new worlds...

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: The fleet commanders are nervous. They've agreed to remain at their given coordinates and await his orders.  But they're anxious to know what's going on here.

Speaker: donatra
Dialogue: I don't blame them.  We can't keep them in the dark forever.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: Don't you agree?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Yet for generations one of those planets has been without a voice. We will be silent no longer.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Join us, Commanders.  Now what's the disposition of the fleet?

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: They're holding position.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: And?

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: They will obey, Praetor.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: It's imperative we retain their allegiance or our great mission will be strangled before it can truly draw breath.

Speaker: donatra
Dialogue: They support your intentions, sir. But they require evidence of your... sincerity.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: And they'll have it.  Tell the fleet that the days of negotiation and diplomacy are over. The Almighty Federation will fall before us.  As I promised you.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: The time we have dreamed of is at hand.  The time... of conquest.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Cut off the dragon's head and it cannot strike back.

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: How many Warbirds will you need?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: None.

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: Praetor.  You have the whole fleet at your disposal.  They supported the coup, they'll follow you.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: The Scimitar will serve my needs.

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: But surely --

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I came this far alone...  We came this far alone.  We require no assistance from the fleet.  Now leave me to my thoughts.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Are we prepared?

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: Yes, Praetor.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: So many years for this moment.  Bring him to me.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: I won't do it.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: It's tradition,Worf.  You of all people should appreciate that!  Besides, I've already seen it.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: A warrior does not appear without his clothing.  It leaves him... vulnerable.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: I don't think we're going to see much combat on Betazed.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: Don't be too sure.  Mother will be there.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: I won't do it.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Won't do what, Mister Worf?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Captain.  I think it is inappropriate for a Starfleet officer to appear...  ... naked.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Come now, a big, strapping fellow like you?  What are you afraid of?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: I'm picking up an unusual electromagnetic signature from the Kolarin system.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What sort of signature?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Positronic.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: It's very faint but I've isolated it to the third planet in the Kolarin system.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What do we know about the planet?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Uncharted.  We'll have to get closer for a more detailed scan.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Theories?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Since positronic signatures have only been known to emanate from androids such as myself, it is logical to theorize that there is an android such as myself on Kolarus III.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: How many of you did Dr. Soong make?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I thought only me, myself and Lore.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Diverting to the Kolarin system takes us awfully close to the Romulan Neutral Zone.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Still well on our side...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I think it's worth a look.  Don't worry, Number One, we'll get you to Betazed with time to spare.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Thank you, sir...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Where we will all honor the Betazoid traditions.  No cold feet, or any other parts of our anatomy. Now, if you'll excuse me.  I'll be in the gym.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: -- Warp Seven.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Engage.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: You better believe you're engaged!

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: What do you think, Data, a long- lost relative?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: I read six distinct positronic signatures, spread out over a few kilometers on the surface.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What do we know about the population?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Isolated pockets of humanoids.  It appears to be a pre-warp civilization at an early stage of industrial development.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Captain, I don't recommend transporting, that ion storm doesn't look very neighborly.  It could head this way without much warning.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Understood.  Data, Worf, you're with me.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Captain, I hope I don't have to remind you --

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I appreciate your concern, Number One, but I've been itching to try out the Argo.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Sir --

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Captain's prerogative, Will. There's no foreseeable danger... and your wife would never forgive me if anything happened to you.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You have the bridge, Mister Troi!

Speaker: data
Dialogue: The closest signature is two kilometers to the west... that direction, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Thank you, Data.  Let's see what she can do.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I will always be baffled by the human predilection for piloting vehicles at unsafe velocities.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Over that rise, sir... half a kilometer.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: It appears to be...  ... an arm.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Why is it moving?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Like me, it has been designed with modular power sources.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Mister Worf, if you please.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: The next signature is one kilometer to the south.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: The final signature is approximately 300 meters up that incline.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Mister Worf, accompany Data please.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: To find the head, sir?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: If you don't mind.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Ten meters...

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I think it unlikely you will need your phaser to recover the cranial unit.  Of course, it could bite you.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: It's you.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: The resemblance is... striking.

Speaker: head
Dialogue: Why am I looking at me?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: You are not looking at yourself. You are looking at me.

Speaker: head
Dialogue: You do not look like me.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I would like to pick you up now. May I do that?

Speaker: head
Dialogue: You have a pretty shirt.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Fascinating...

Speaker: head
Dialogue: I have two arms and ten fingers. Do you know where my arms are?  I cannot see where we are going. Where are we going?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Commander!

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: STOP TALKING!

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: If you wouldn't mind.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: head
Dialogue: You have a shiny head.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: He is very observant.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I can see that.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Captain!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Shall we try some "unsafe velocities?"

Speaker: head
Dialogue: You have a red shirt.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: This is not an appropriate time for a conversation.

Speaker: head
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Because the captain has to concentrate on piloting the vehicle.

Speaker: head
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Data!

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Sorry, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Mister Data.  Let's make like the wind.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: He must have Klingon blood.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: I think you have nicer eyes.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Our eyes are identical, Doctor.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Geordi?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Well, he seems to have the same internal mechanics as Data but not as much positronic development. The neural pathways aren't nearly as sophisticated.  I'd say he's a prototype.  Something Dr. Soong created before Data.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Do you have a name, sir?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Be-nign.  Dr. Soong's penchant for whimsical names seems to have no end.

Speaker: head
Dialogue: You have a fuzzy face.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Keep me informed, Number One, and, please, put him back together.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Can you tell me how you came to be on the planet where we found you?

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Excuse me.  I have some diagnostics to run on some medical scanner things.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Duty calls, gentlemen.  Carry on.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Yes, please continue.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Do you know who I am?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: No.  My name is Data... I am your brother.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: ... and after the ceremony on Betazed, three entire weeks for our honeymoon.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: We're going sailing on the Opal Sea.  We've booked an old-fashioned solar catamaran.  Just us and the sun and the waves.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: It seems a very... soft honeymoon.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: It's meant to be relaxing.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: A Klingon honeymoon begins with the Kholamar desert march where the couple bonds in endurance trials. If they survive the challenge they move on to the Fire Caves of Fek'lhr to face the demons of Gre'thor.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Well, that sounds relaxing too.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: It is... invigorating.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: So they've got him up and running.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: He's a very unusual android

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Runs in the family.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Earl Grey, hot.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Come.  Counselor.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: Do you have a moment, sir?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Of course, sit down.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: It's about Data  I've watched him with the B-9 and I'm troubled. Data's desire for a "family" is very strong.  I'm afraid he may be

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You're speaking of emotional investment?

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: The B-9 is like a slow child, sir. And Data, in his own way, has assumed the position of a parent or guardian.  I'm afraid he has expectations based on his own experiences.  He'll be disappointed when the B-9 cannot meet those expectations.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: As much as we care for him, Deanna... we have to remember that Data isn't capable of disappointment.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: I don't believe that, sir.  We've shared many disappointing journeys.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I'm going to miss you.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: And I you.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Acknowledged...  ... I'll talk to Data

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Admiral Janeway.  Good to see you.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: With or without the rest of the fleet?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: New Praetor?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Understood.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Not with the Romulans.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Just lucky, Admiral.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Lay in a new course... Take us to Romulus.  Warp eight.

Speaker: helm officer
Dialogue: Aye aye, sir.  Course plotted and laid in...

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Romulus?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I'm afraid the Opal Sea will have to wait, Number One... Engage.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: As you can see the habitable half of Remus is always in darkness because, like Mercury, one side always faces the sun.  Due to the extreme temperatures on that half of their world, the Remans live on the dark side of the planet.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Almost nothing is known about the Reman homeworld, although intelligence scans have proven the existence of dilithium mining and heavy weapons construction.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: The Remans themselves are considered an undesirable caste in the hierarchy of the Empire.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: But they also have the reputation of being formidable warriors.  In the Dominion War, Reman forces were used as assault troops in the most violent encounters.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Cannon fodder.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Then how did a Reman get to be Praetor?  I don't get it.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: We have to assume he had Romulan collaborators.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: A coup d'etat?

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: The Praetor's power has always been the Romulan fleet.  They must be behind him.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What have you learned about Shinzon?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Starfleet intelligence was only able to provide a partial account of his military record.  We can infer he is relatively young and a capable commander.  He fought seventeen major engagements in the war.  All successful.  Beyond that, we know nothing.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Well... it seems we're truly sailing into the unknown.  Keep at it.  Anything you can give me would be appreciated.  Dismissed.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: At present he serves no useful function.  Dr. Soong created us to become active and useful members of society.  I do not believe he would have wanted the B-9 to live out his life in his present state.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: I can't believe the Captain went along with a memory download.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Captain Picard agrees that the B-9 was probably designed with the same self-actualization parameters as myself.  If my memory engrams are successfully integrated into his positronic matrix, he should have all my abilities.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: He'd have all your memories too. You feel comfortable with that?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I feel nothing, Geordi.  It is my belief that with my memory engrams he will be able to function as a more complete individual.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: An individual more like you, you mean.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Maybe he's not supposed to be like you.  Maybe he's supposed to be just like he is.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Okay... we're done.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Do you know where you are?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Can you remember our father?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Do you know the name of the Captain of this vessel?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Is that your final answer?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Do you know my name?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Data, he's assimilating a lot of programming.  Remember, he's a prototype, a lot less sophisticated than you are.  We just don't know if his matrix will be able to adapt.  Or if he'll be able to retain anything.  We should give him some time.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: What purpose does this serve?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: It seems to be a redundant memory port.  Maybe it's for provisional memory storage in case his neural pathways overload?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Dr. Soong must have found it unnecessary in later versions.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: It's possible the extra memory port is interfering with the engram processing.  Mind if I keep him here and run some diagnostics?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: No, I do not mind.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: But I believe he will prove incapable of performing higher functions.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Don't give up hope, Data.  I know, I know, you're not capable of hope.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I am not.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: No, remain with Commander La Forge. He is going to try to make you well.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Why don't they answer our hails?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: It's an old psychological strategy, Number One.  To put him in a position of dominance and make us uneasy.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: It's working.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Counselor?

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: They're out there, sir.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Sir,  I recommend we raise shields.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Not yet, Mister Worf.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Captain, with all due respect to diplomatic protocols -- the Federation Council's not sitting out here, we are.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Patience.  Diplomacy is a very exacting occupation.  We can wait.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Captain...

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: My God...

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Should I raise shields?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Captain -- !

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Tactical analysis, Mister Worf.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Fifty-two disruptor banks, twenty- seven photon torpedo bays, primary and secondary phased shields.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: She's not out for a pleasure cruise.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: She's a predator.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: We're being hailed.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: On screen.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Praetor Shinzon, I'm pleased to --

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Not very chatty.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Away team.  Transporter room four.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Praetor Shinzon?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Captain Picard... Jean Luc Picard... I don't mean to stare, it's just -- well, you can't imagine how long I've been waiting for this moment.  I always imagined you taller, isn't that odd?  You may scan me without subterfuge, Commander Data.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: And you're not as we imagined you.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: No?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: You are human.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Commander Worf.  I greet you as a valiant warrior... and as my brother.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: I'll save my greetings for a better brother.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Why have you asked for our presence here?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Praetor?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I've never met a human woman.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: I'm only half human.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Deanna Troi of Betazed.  Empathic and telepathic abilities, ship's counselor.  All of this I knew... But I didn't know you were so beautiful.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: You seem very familiar with our personnel.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I am, Commander Riker...  ... May I touch your hair?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Praetor, we've come to Romulus on a matter we were -- assured was of great importance.  If you have anything to say to us as representatives of the Federation, I suggest you do so now.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: On the world I come from there's no light.  No sun.  Beauty isn't important.  I see now there's a world elsewhere.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Praetor Shinzon.  We're not here to discuss your lack of a social life.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: There's so much we have to talk about.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I would be interested to know what we are talking about.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Unity, Captain!  Tearing down the walls between us to recognize we are one people.  Federation and Romulan.  Human and Vulcan and Klingon and Reman.  I'm speaking of the thing that makes us the same. We want peace.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I want to end the centuries of mistrust.  I want to be your ally, not your enemy.  As a first step I propose we eliminate the Neutral Zone and begin a free and open exchange of goods and ideas.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: And the Senate supports you?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I have dissolved the Senate.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Right now, you're thinking this all sounds too good to be true?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: And you're wondering why the Scimitar is so well armed.  Is this the ship of a peacemaker?  Or a predator?  ... But you're also thinking the chance for peace is too promising to ignore.  Above all, you're trying to decide if you can trust me.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Then perhaps the time has come to add some illumination to our discussion.  Computer, raise lighting four levels.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Allow me to tell you a story that I hope will clarify my position. When I was very young I was stricken with an odd disease.  I developed a hyper-sensitivity to sound.  The slightest whisper caused me agony...

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: No one knew what to do.  Finally I was taken to a doctor who had some experience with Terran illnesses and I was finally diagnosed with Shalaft's syndrome.  Do you know of it, Captain?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You know I do.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Then you know it's a very rare syndrome.  Genetic.  All the male members of my family had it. Eventually I was treated.  Now I can hear as well as you can, Captain.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I can see as well as you can.  I can feel everything you feel.  In fact, I feel exactly what you feel.  Don't I, Jean Luc?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Do you trust me now?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: We need to talk, just you and I.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Come to dinner on Romulus tomorrow. Just the two of us.  Or just the one of us.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You know I need to verify this.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Tomorrow then, Captain.  We have so much to discuss.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Picard to Enterprise.  Five to beam out.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: There's no doubt, Captain.  Right down to your regressive strain of Shalaft's Syndrome.  He's a clone.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: When was he... created?

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: About twenty-five years ago.  They probably used a hair follicle or skin cell.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I think a skin cell's the more likely of the two.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Believe me, Number One; I'm going to find out.  Contact Starfleet Command and inform them of the situation.  I need to know where the hell he came from.  Deanna.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: I would say he's been trained to resist telepathy.  What I could sense of his emotions were erratic, very hard to follow.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Is he sincere about wanting peace?

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: I don't know.  The same way you want to know him.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: How could I not?

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: Captain, don't assume he's anything like you are.  You should resist the urge to think you know him.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I not only know him, Deanna, I am him... and he is me!

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: Will, you need to rest.  As ship's counselor, I'm recommending you get me sleep.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Some honeymoon.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: We have time.  Come to bed.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Imzadi, what am I going to do with you?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Imzadi.  This is so good.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: He can never know you as I know you... He can never touch you as I touch you.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: This isn't real.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Can you feel my hands... are they real?  Can you feel my lips, my loins?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I'll always be with you now.  Now and forever...

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: You sick bastard!

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Deanna?!  What's with the name calling?

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: ... then I don't understand the reason for the delay!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: You don't have to understand.

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: And bringing the Enterprise here?! What possible purpose could that serve?!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I have a purpose.

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: Then perhaps you will enlighten us?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Silence, Romulan!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: You must learn patience, Commander. Do you know where I learned it?  In the dilithium mines of Remus. Spend eighteen hours every day under the lash of a Romulan guard's whip and you'll soon understand patience.

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: Praetor.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Now go.  I have some personal business.

Speaker: donatra
Dialogue: How long before he has us in the dilithium mines?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: And when I was ready they were going to replace you with me, an exact biological duplicate.  Put a Romulan agent at the heart of Starfleet to influence your command structure.  It was a bold plan.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: As happens so frequently here on Romulus, a new government came to power.  They decided to abandon the plan -- frankly, I think they were afraid I'd be discovered and it would lead to war.  They weren't ready for that.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Romulan ale -- I'm surprised.  I can't stand it.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You'll acquire a taste for it.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: It's not quite the face you remember.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Not quite.  I envy the hairline.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: A lifetime of violence will do that.  My nose was broken four times.  And my jaw... But so much is the same.  The eyes, you recognize the eyes.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes.  The eyes have it.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Our eyes reflect our lives, don't they?  Yours are so confident.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: How did you end up on Remus?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: They sent me there to die.  How could a mere human survive the dilithium mines?  It was...  ... I was a slave.  And a monster. The only thing the Romulan guards hated more than the Remans was me. But one man took pity on me: the man who became my Viceroy.  He taught me how to survive.  And in that dark place, where there was nothing of myself, I found my Reman brothers.  They showed me the only kindness I ever knew.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: For thousands of years the Romulan Senate has met in this chamber and dictated the fate of its sister- planet... But the time has come for us to live as equals.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You're doing this to liberate the Remans?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: No race should be a slave to another.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: You don't trust me.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I have no reason to.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Of course you do.  If you had lived my life and experienced the suffering of my people... you'd be sitting where I am now.  At least I hope you would.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: And if you had lived my life you would understand that there is a great responsibility in representing the Federation.  I can't let my personal feelings unduly influence my decisions.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: All I have is my personal feelings. I wasn't raised with the ideals of the Federation.  But I'm trying to understand them now.  To live up to them   To live up to you.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I want to know where I come from. The Remans gave me a future.  You can tell me about my past.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: There's so much, and so much of it is dull...

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Were we always explorers?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Looking up at the stars.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: And you dreamed about what was up there.  About...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: New worlds.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: After you, Praetor.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Age before rank, Jean Luc.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: So I'm not as tall as you expected?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I always hoped I would hit two meters.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: With a full head of hair.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: There is that.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Shinzon... I'm trying to believe you.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: If there's one ideal the Federation holds most dear it's that all men, all races, can be united.  From the first time the Vulcans came to Earth we've sought a future of peace.  Nothing would make me more proud than to take your hand in friendship.  In time.  When trust has been earned.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I'm honored to think I might someday speak with such eloquence.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: In time, Jean Luc.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: In time.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: This is a mistake.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: He's gentler than I thought.  And he has a sense of humor.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: Don't forget our mission, Shinzon. We should act.  Now.  Time is running out.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: My time.  I'll spend it how I choose.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: We'll return to the Scimitar. Prepare yourself for the bonding.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Sir, we've had an unauthorized access into the main computer.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Who was it?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: It's going to take some time to find out -- the data stream was rerouted through substations all over the ship.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What programs were accessed?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: That's what I don't get -- it's mostly basic stellar cartography: star charts; communications protocols; some uplinks from colony tracking stations.  It's not even restricted material.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Set up a security program to detect any unusual data stream rerouting. If it happens again, we want to be ready.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: When the Scimitar decloaked there was a momentary spike in the tertiary EM band -- there -- You're not going to believe this but it's Thalaron.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: ... I thought Thalaron radiation was theoretical.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Which is why our initial scans didn't pick it up.  But he's got it, Captain.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: As I remember, Thalaron research was banned in the Federation because of its bioqenic properties.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: It has the ability to consume organic material at the subatomic level.  I can't overestimate the danger of Thalaron radiation, Jean Luc.  A microscopic amount could kill every living thing on this ship in a matter of seconds.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Understood.  Keep on it.  I need to know what he has and how to neutralize any threat.  Give me options.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Doctor, will you excuse us for a moment?  Geordi, please come with me.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Come...  ... Beverly, come in.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: You're working late.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Remember him?

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: He was a bit proud as I recall.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: He was a damn fool.  Selfish and ambitious.  Very much in need of seasoning.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: He turned out all right.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I so wanted to believe Shinzon. But the Thalaron radiation can't be explained away.  Whatever he's after, it's not peace.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Is he very much like you were?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: On my way...

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Jean Luc -- whatever you were -- right now you're the man you've made yourself.  He's someone else.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I wish I could believe that, Doctor.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: You're not here.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: ... To leave all of this behind and be with me.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I can feel your desire, Deanna...

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I can feel your hunger to know the Reman ways... the old ways.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Don't fear what you desire...

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: The bond is broken.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Find her again.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: No -- this is wasting time.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Do as I tell you!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: On my way.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: It's accelerating.  You have no more time for games.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Have the doctors prepare.  I'll be on the bridge.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Transport.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Welcome home.  Begin the download.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Tea, hot.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Aside from slightly elevated adrenalin and serotonin levels, you're completely normal.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Can you describe it, Deanna?

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: It was... a violation.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: Shinzon's Viceroy seems to have the ability to reach into my thoughts. I've become a liability... I request to be relieved of my duties.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Permission denied.  If you can possibly endure any more of these assaults.  I need you at my side. Now more than ever I...

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Worf!  Raise Shields !

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Hello, Jean Luc.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Why am I here?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I was lonely...  Perhaps I'm not aging as well as you did.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I need a sample of your blood. What do your Borg friends say? Resistance is futile.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Yes.  The bait you couldn't refuse. I learned there might be an existing prototype from a Cardassian historian, then went to a great deal of trouble to find it and scatter it about on Kolarus III.  I knew it would pique your curiosity and conveniently make the Enterprise the closest ship to Romulus when I contacted Starfleet.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: All of this so you could capture me?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Don't be so vain.  After we found it, we made a few modifications. An extra memory port, a hidden transponder.  Perhaps your eyes will be a bit less confident when you learn I've gained access to Starfleet's communications protocols.  I now know the location of your entire fleet...  ... You may go.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Out of my sight.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Maybe I'll train it to do little tricks for me like your robot does. Or maybe I'll snap its ugly head off.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What's this all about?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: It's about destiny, Picard.  About a Reman outcast who --

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You're not Reman.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: And I'm not quite human.  So what am I?  What do you see?  Do you see a life you might have led?  Lost youth never to be recaptured?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I see a young man trying desperately to deny who he is.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I see an old man, set in his ways, afraid to live without a uniform to prop him up and a Starfleet regulation to tell him what to do. I see the man I will never be.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I won't defend my life to you.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: My life is meaningless as long as you're alive.  What am I while you exist?  A shadow?  An enigma?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: If your issues are with me... This has nothing to do with my ship and nothing to do with the Federation.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Oh, but it does.  We will no longer bow like slaves before anyone.  Not the Romulans and not your mighty Federation.  We're a race bred for war.  For conquest.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Think about what you're doing, Shinzon.  Are you ready to plunge the entire quadrant into war to satisfy your own personal demons?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: It amazes me how little you know yourself.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I'm incapable of such an act, and so are you.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I think the facts speak for themselves.  The same noble Picard blood runs in our veins.  Had you lived my life, you'd be doing exactly as I am.  Look in the mirror, and see yourself.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Consider that, Captain.  I can think of no greater torment for you.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: It's a mirror for you as well...

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Not for long, Captain.  I'm afraid you won't survive to witness the victory of the echo over the voice.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: No response to our hails.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: His cloak is perfect... no tachyon emissions, no residual antiprotons.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Keep at it, Geordi.  Find a way in.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Will, I need to talk to you.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: Where are you taking him?

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: So, human... you've met your better self!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What are you doing to Counsellor Troi?

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: I'm preparing her for Shinzon... To sooth him as she soothes you.  To stand at his side as she does at yours.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: That will never happen.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: Listen to him, android.  Such a small and weak creature.  Yet he roars so valiantly...  It would take me but an instant to tear that valiant heart from your chest.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: There'll be another after me.  And another after that.  You'll find we're a resilient species.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: I look forward to the sport.  Take him.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Be careful of over-playing your part, Commander!

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Sorry, sir.  I thought it added a touch of reality to the performance.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: My mission was a success, sir.  I have discovered the source of the Thalaron radiation.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Good work.  The download?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: He believes he has our communications protocols.  But they will give him inaccurate locations for all Starfleet vessels.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Move, puny human animal.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: A bit less florid, Data.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Aye, sir... This way.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: This entire ship is, essentially, a flying Thalaron generator.  All its power relays lead to that device.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: A weapon.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: It would appear so.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Geordi equipped me with the prototype for the Emergency Transport Unit.  I recommend you use it to return to the Enterprise.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: It'll only work for one of us.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: We'll find a way off together. Recommendations?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: There is a shuttlebay 948 meters from our current location.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: Where's Picard?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: This way, sir!

Speaker: data
Dialogue: It seems to have an encrypted security system.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Alacrity would be appreciated, Commander.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: They are trying to override the access codes.  Reman is really a most complex language with pictographs representing certain verb roots and --

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: While I find that fascinating, Data, we really need that Goddamned door open!

Speaker: data
Dialogue: According to the ship's manifest they are Scorpion-class attack fliers.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What do you imagine this is?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Port thrusters, sir.  Would you like me to drive?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Can you open the shuttlebay doors?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Affirmative, sir.  Negative, sir. They have instigated security overrides and erected a force field around the external portals.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Well then... only one way to go.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Do you think this is a wise course of action?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: We're about to find out... Power up disruptors and fire on my mark.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Ready, Captain.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Fire!

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Worf!  Lock on transporters!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Tractor beam!  Now!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Number One, emergency warp!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: The Enterprise is immaterial!  They won't make it back to Federation space.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I thought we discussed patience, Commander.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Commander Suran, the games are over.  In two days the Federation will be crippled beyond repair. Does that satisfy you?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: And when I return... you and I shall have a little talk about showing proper respect!

Speaker: donatra
Dialogue: Does anyone in this room harbor any illusions about what he means by "showing proper respect"?

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: I want opinions.  He is clearly out of his mind.

Speaker: suran
Dialogue: But can he complete his mission?

Speaker: donatra
Dialogue: Should he?

Speaker: donatra
Dialogue: Are you prepared to have your hands drenched in blood?  He'll show them no mercy.  And his sins will mark us all for generations.  Is that what you truly want, Romulans?

Speaker: donatra
Dialogue: I think you should consider that question now -- or else you may have a lifetime to think about it in the dilithium mines.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: The more I studied his DNA the more confusing it got.  Finally I could only come to one conclusion... Shinzon was created with temporal RNA sequencing.  He was designed so that at a certain point his aging process could be accelerated to reach your age more quickly, so he could replace you.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: But the Romulans abandoned the plan...

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: As a result the temporal sequencing was never activated.  Remember, he was supposed to replace you at nearly your current age.  He was engineered to skip thirty years of life.  But since the RNA sequencing was never activated, his cellular structure has started to break down.  He's dying.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Dying?

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: He wasn't designed to live a complete, human life span.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Not without a complete myelodysplastic infusion from the only donor with compatible DNA. But that would mean draining all your blood.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: That's why he went to all that trouble to capture you.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: I can't be sure but the rate of decay seems to be accelerating.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Then he'll come for me as a donor.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: No, I have only activated your cognitive and communication subroutines.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Because you are dangerous.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: You have been programmed to gather information that can be used against this ship.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Do you know anything about Shinzon's plans against the Federation?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Do you have any knowledge of the tactical abilities of his ship?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: No.  I must deactivate you.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Indefinitely.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: A long time, brother.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: It's called a Cascading Biogenic Pulse.  The unique properties of Thalaron radiation allow the energy beam to expand almost without limits.  Depending on the radiant intensity it could encompass a ship... or a planet.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: And that's exactly what he's going to do.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: His hatred of the Federation is apparent.  He would have built a weapon of that scope for one reason.  He is going after Earth.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Oh boy.  Destroy humanity and the Federation is crippled...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: And the Romulans invade.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: How can you be certain?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I know how he thinks.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: And there's no way to penetrate his cloak?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: He could pass within 10 meters of every ship in Starfleet and they'd never know.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: But we do have one advantage.  He needs your blood to live.  He might come after you first.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I'm counting on it... We've been ordered to head to sector 3274. Starfleet is diverting the fleet to meet us there.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Strength in numbers?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: We can only hope so.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: He can't be allowed to use that weapon.  All other concerns are secondary.  Do you understand me?

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: All hands.  Battle stations.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: To seek out new life and new civilizations.  Zephyr Cochran's own words.  When Charles Darwin set out on the H.M.S. Beagle, on his journey into the unknown... he sailed without a single musket.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: That was another time.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: How far we've come.  Let me know if you need anything.

Speaker: beverly
Dialogue: Jean Luc...  ... He is not you.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What makes us who we are, Doctor? Can you tell me that?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: How long?

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: A matter of hours now --

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: If you don't begin the procedure soon you'll never make it back to Romulus.  You shouldn't have delayed.  You should have killed Picard the moment --

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: How long until we reach the Rift?

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: Seven minutes.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Show me our current position.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: How long until we reach the fleet?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: At our current velocity we will arrive at sector 3274 in approximately 40 minutes.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: "For now we see but through a glass darkly..."  He said he's a mirror.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Of you?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I do not agree.  Although you share the same genetic structure, the events of your life have created unique individual.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: But so much is the same.  On a biological level he is... and I will not accept the idea that there is nothing I can do.  I have a responsibility to try to make a human connection with him.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: He would deny a "human" connection is possible.  He considers himself entirely Reman.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: He may have already rejected my humanity, but you also have a twin.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: No, sir, it is not possible.  The B-9 is physically identical to me, although his neural pathways are not as advanced.  But even if they were, he would not be me.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: How can you be sure?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: I aspire, sir.  To be better than I am.  The B-9 does not.  Nor does Shinzon.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: We'll never know what Shinzon might have been.  Had he stood where I did as a child?  And looked up at the stars.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: We are passing through the Bassen Rift.  The projections will return when we have cleared it.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: It's interfering with our uplink from Starfleet cartography?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Yes, sir.  The Rift effects all long-range communications --

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Commander Riker, evasive maneuvers!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Target weapons systems and shields. I don't want the Enterprise destroyed.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Can you learn to see in the dark, Captain?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Report.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: He's firing through his cloak.  We can't get a lock.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: He disabled our warp drive with his first shot.  We've only got impulse.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Long range communication is impossible as long as we're in the rift --

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Worf, prepare a full phaser spread, zero elevation.  All banks on my mark.  Scan for shield impacts and stand by photon torpedoes.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Aye, sir

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Fire!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: You're too slow, old man.  Attack pattern Shinzon Theta.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: We are losing dorsal shields --

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Full axis rotation to port!  Fire all ventral phasers!

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Minimal damage to the Scimitar.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Defensive pattern Kirk Epsilon. Geordi, get those shields online.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Counselor Troi, report to the bridge.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Unless we can disable his cloak we're just going to be firing in the dark.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Sir, we're being hailed.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: On screen.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: You can't trace my holographic emitters, Captain.  So don't bother.  And you can't contact Starfleet.  We're quite alone.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: We are.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: It's just the two of us now, Jean Luc, as it should be... Your ship and mine... You and me.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Why are you here?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: To accept your surrender.  I can clearly destroy you at any time. Lower your shields and allow me to transport you to my ship.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: And what of the Enterprise?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I have little interest in your quaint vessel, Captain.  If the Enterprise will withdraw to a distance of one hundred light years, it will not be harmed.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You know that's not possible.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I know... you'll all gladly die to save your home world.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Look at me, Shinzon!  Do you feel the blood pumping inside you?  Your hands, your eyes, your nature, are the same as mine.  Buried deep inside you beneath the years of pain and anger is a capacity you've forgotten.  It's the one way our mirror can reflect the two of us exactly because it's the very thing that truly defines us.  To be human is to try to make yourself better than you are.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I know you as well as I know myself, Shinzon.  There was a time you looked at the stars and dreamed of what might be.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Long ago.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Not so long.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Childish dreams, Captain.  Lost in the dilithium mines of Remus.  I'm what you see now.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I see more than what you are.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I see what you could be.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: The man who is Jean Luc Picard and Shinzon of Remus won't exterminate the population of an entire planet! He is better than that!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: He is what his life has made him!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: And what will he do with that life?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: If I were to beam to your ship... let you complete your medical procedure, give you a full life... what would you do with the time?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You once asked me about your past. Your history.  When I was your age, I burned with ambition.  I was very proud and my pride often hurt people.  I made every wrong choice a young man can... But one thing saved me... I had a father who believed in me.  Who took the time to teach me a better way.  You have the same father.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: So if I gave you my life, what would you do with it?  Would you spend the years in a blaze of hatred as you are now?  Or could you change?  Could you try to remember a mother's touch you never felt?  A father's words you never heard?  Could you do that?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: But you want to.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Let me tell you about our father.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: That's your life... not mine.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: It's too late.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You can still make a choice!  Make the right one now!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I have no choices!  I can't fight what I am!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I'll show you my true nature.  Your nature.  And as Earth dies -- remember that I'm forever Shinzon of Remus!  And my voice will echo through time long after yours has faded to a dim memory.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Disable their weapons!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Report!

Speaker: reman officer
Dialogue: Two ships decloaking, sir! Romulan!

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Believe it or not, I think the cavalry has arrived.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: We're being hailed.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: On screen.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Your timing is impeccable, Commander.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: When this is over, I owe you a drink.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: You heard the lady.  Get to work. Move your ass!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Coordinate our attack with the Valdore's tactical officer. Triangulate fire on any shield impacts.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Aye, sir.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Aft shields are down to forty percent.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Keep our bow to the Scimitar. Auxiliary power to forward shields.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Target the flanking Warbird.  All forward disruptor banks on my mark.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Forward shields are down to ten percent.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Bring us about!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Let her pursue -- drop cloak on the aft port quadrant and prepare for full emergency stop.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: What?!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: You heard me.

Speaker: donatra
Dialogue: She's losing her cloak!  Stand by all forward disruptor banks!

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: She's almost on us.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Not yet.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: Praetor...

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: FULL STOP AND FIRE !

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Restore the aft cloak.and bring us about.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Do you have life support?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Understood --

Speaker: data
Dialogue: We have lost structural integrity on decks twelve through seventeen, sections four through ten.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Emergency force fields are holding.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Evacuate those decks and reroute field power to forward shields.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: Captain -- I might have a way to find them.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Counselor?

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: The one thing he may have forgotten in the course of battle: me.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Make it so.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Prepare a lateral run -- all starboard disruptors.

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: He's resisting me.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: What is it?!  Focus on your job!!!

Speaker: viceroy
Dialogue: She is here.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: Remember me?

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: NOW!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Savage them!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Prepare a boarding party -- BRING ME PICARD!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Get the cloak back!  And target shield coordinates beta three.  All disruptors.  Fire!

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Captain, we have lost ventral shielding on deck twenty nine.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Divert power and compensate --

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Intruder alert!

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Let's go.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Security detail to deck twenty nine.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Worf.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: He's getting his cloak back.  We have exhausted our compliment of photon torpedoes.  Phaser banks are down to four percent.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What if we target all phasers in a concentrated attack?

Speaker: data
Dialogue: The Scimitar's shields are still at seventy percent.  It would make no difference, sir.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: They're stopping...

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: What's he doing?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: He wants to look me in the eye.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: He thinks he knows exactly what I'm going to do...

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: We've got him!

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Open a channel.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: We are being hailed.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Deanna, stand by.  Open a channel.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I never told you about my first Academy evaluation, did I?  I received very high marks for my studies.  But I was found lacking in certain other areas. Personality traits, you might say. In particular I was thought to be extremely...  ... over-confident.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Geordi, put 211 power to the engines.  Take it from life support if you have to -- everything you can give me.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Aye, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Deanna, on my mark.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Ready, sir!

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: ENGAGE.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: HARD TO PORT !

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Divert all power to engines.  Full reverse!

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Don't worry -- Hell is dark.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Data, I need you.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Computer.  Auto-destruct sequence Omega.  Zero time delay.  Recognize voice pattern Jean Luc Picard. Authorization Alpha Alpha Three Zero Five --

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Target disruptors.  Destroy them.

Speaker: reman officer
Dialogue: Disruptors are off-line, sir.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Deploy the weapon.  Kill everything on that ship.  Then set a course for Earth.

Speaker: reman officer
Dialogue: What about Picard?

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Our greater goal is more important, brother.

Speaker: reman officer
Dialogue: But, Praetor, you won't survive without him...

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: Some ideals are worth dying for, aren't they, Jean Luc?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: How long until he can fire?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: The targeting sequence should take about four minutes.

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: But how can he?  He'll kill you.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: This isn't about me anymore.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Prepare for a site-to-site transport.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Sir, we won't be able to bring you back.  It's a one way trip. Captain, I don't know if the transporter --

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: That's an order, Commander.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Sir, allow me to go.  You are needed here.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Negative.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Sir...

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: Let him go.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Now, Mister La Forge.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Aye, sir.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: That's it.  Transporters are down.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Counsellor Troi, please assume command.  Geordi, if you will come with me.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: What is our approximate distance?

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: 400 meters.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Thank you, Geordi.  Deactivate the field.

Speaker: shinzon
Dialogue: I'm glad we're together now -- our destiny is complete.

Speaker: data
Dialogue: Goodbye.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: Data.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: Sir, we're being hailed.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: On screen...  ... Open a channel.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Thank you, Commander.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Geordi... prepare the shuttlebay for arrivals.  They don't know our procedures so just... open the doors.

Speaker: geordi
Dialogue: I'll take care of it, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Number One.  You have the bridge.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: To absent friends... o family.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I don't know if all this has made sense to you, but I wanted you to know what kind of man he was.  In his quest to be more like us, he helped show us what it means to be human.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: No, he wasn't... But his wonder and his curiosity about every facet of human life helped all of us see the best parts of ourselves.  He embraced change... because he always wanted to be more than he was.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Well, I hope someday you will.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: On my way.  Please notify Commander Riker...  ... We'll talk later?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I'm sorry you won't be here for the re-fit, but I know the Titan needs you immediately.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: The Titan's a fine ship, Will.  And she's getting a captain worthy of her.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: She's the most beautiful ship I've ever seen.  ... But she's not the Enterprise.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I promise you in time, she'll become your home... If I could offer you one piece of advice?

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Anything.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: When your first officer insists that you can't go on away missions... Ignore him --

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: I intend to.

Speaker: riker
Dialogue: Serving with you has been an honor.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: The honor was mine.  Captain Riker.

Speaker: madden
Dialogue: So... what's the old man like?

Speaker: ops officer
Dialogue: Why don't you go in and find out?

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Reminds me of a young doctor I used to know...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Not tonight, I have work here.

Speaker: madden
Dialogue: Commander Martin Madden reporting for duty, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Welcome aboard, Commander.  I hope, your transfer didn't come as too much of a surprise.

Speaker: madden
Dialogue: I was... honored, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: I needed you immediately to help oversee the re-fit...  ... Your service record on the Talos is exemplary, but there are a few things I would like to discuss with you regarding my requirements for a First Officer.  Shall we say dinner in my quarters at 1900 hours?

Speaker: madden
Dialogue: Very good, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Commander, I don't know how they did it on the Talos, but we have door chimes on the Enterprise.  We use them.

Speaker: madden
Dialogue: Yes, sir.  Sorry, sir.

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: You don't understand the Captain -- there should be no changes until we have discussed the modifications with him.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: Your new chair, sir.

Speaker: ensign
Dialogue: It's the Mark Seven, Captain. State-of-the-art ergonomics... command interfaces with --

Speaker: worf
Dialogue: I told him you're comfortable with your old chair.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Let's give it a try.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Feels good.

Speaker: ensign
Dialogue: Try that button, sir.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: It's about time.

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: Commander, please sit down...

Speaker: picard
Dialogue: ... We've received our first assignment.  We're going to be exploring the Denab system.  It should be exciting.  It's a place... where no one has gone before.
